item.title: Republicans pushing to embrace mail-in voting encounter widespread resistance
item.dc:creator: Natasha Korecki and Matt Dixon and Abigail Brooks and Emma Barnett and Jake Traylor and Alex Tabet and Nnamdi Egwuonwu and Katherine Koretski and Sarah Dean and Steve Patterson
item.description: Trump's repeated attacks on mail-in voting have made it tougher for Republicans who see a desperate need for the GOP to encourage more ways to cast ballots.

media:content.media:credit: Dustin Franz for The Washington Post via Getty Images file
media:content.media:text: Former President Donald J. Trump gestures to supporters at a rally in Erie, Pa., on July 29, 2023.
media:content.media:description: A large swath of Trump supporters have taken their cues from the former president and don't trust mail-in voting.

media:content.media:text: mail ballots
media:content.media:description: Democrats have been more quicker to embrace mail-in voting in recent election cycles.

item.title: Israeli strike hits aid convoy, killing 7 World Central Kitchen workers in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Associated Press
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Tuesday his country’s forces had “unintentionally hit innocent people” in the Gaza Strip in the past day, after an airstrike killed seven aid workers with the disaster relief charity World Central Kitchen.

media:content.media:text: The international food aid charity said on April 2 it was pausing its Gaza aid operations after seven of its staff were killed in a "targeted Israeli strike" as they unloaded desperately needed food aid delivered by sea from Cyprus.
media:content.media:description: People gather around a World Central Kitchen vehicle that was hit by an Israeli strike the previous day in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Gaza
media:content.media:description: Relatives and friends mourned the deaths as they gathered in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen Aid Worker Funeral
media:content.media:description: The body of a staff member of the U.S.-based aid group was carried through the streets of Rafah during his funeral.

media:content.media:text: World Central Kitchen vehicles struck in Gaza
media:content.media:description: People gathered Tuesday around one of the cars that was hit by the strike in Deir al-Balah in the central Gaza Strip.

item.title: 'I kept on saying goodbye': Gaza hospital reports rise in stillbirths and infant deaths
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva
item.description: Doctors at a Gaza hospital say a growing number of women have suffered pregnancy losses or complications, and there has been a rise in stillbirths and neonatal deaths.

media:content.media:text: premature babies underweight small baby malnourished
media:content.media:description: Premature babies rest at Emirati Hospital in Rafah, Gaza Strip.

item.title: Eight passengers stranded on African island after Norwegian cruise ship left without them
item.dc:creator: Marlene Lenthang and Arnav Jain
item.description: A dream cruise vacation has turned into a nightmare for eight passengers left stranded on the African island of São Tomé and Príncipe after their ship left without them because they were late to return from a private tour.

media:content.media:text: Jill and Jay Campbell.
media:content.media:description: Jill and Jay Campbell.

item.title: Ye wanted to shave Donda Academy students' heads and lock kids in cages, ex-employee says in lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Diana Dasrath and Tim Stelloh
item.description: Donda Academy founder Ye allegedly expressed wanting to shave students’ heads and lock them in cages, according to a lawsuit filed Tuesday by a former employee.

media:content.media:text: Kanye West in Los Angeles on March 21, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Ye in Los Angeles on March 21.

media:content.media:text: The Donda Academy in Simi Valley, Calif.
media:content.media:description: The Donda Academy in Simi Valley, Calif.

item.title: Washington state judge blocks use of AI-enhanced video as evidence in possible first-of-its-kind ruling
item.dc:creator: Tim Stelloh
item.description: A Washington state judge overseeing a triple murder case barred the use of video enhanced by artificial intelligence as evidence in a ruling that experts said may be the first-of-its-kind in a United States criminal court.

media:content.media:text: The Norm Maleng Regional Justice Center
media:content.media:description: The Norm Maleng Regional Justice Center, which houses the King County Superior Court, in Kent, Wash.

item.title: DHS attempts to stop a steady stream of guns from America to Haiti
item.dc:creator: Guad Venegas and Fredlyn Pierre Louis
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security is trying to stop the illegal flow of high-powered guns from the U.S. to Haiti, as the Caribbean nation reels from violence and instability wrought by armed groups and gangs.

media:content.media:text: A G-9 federation gang member holds a gun
media:content.media:description: A G-9 federation gang member in the Delmas 3 area in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Feb. 22, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Confiscated guns lay on a table
media:content.media:description: Weapons confiscated by HSI Miami are displayed during a press conference to announce a crackdown on the smuggling of firearms to Haiti and other Caribbean nations in 2022.

item.title: Eclipse glasses: A look behind the scenes of how they're made
item.dc:creator: Maura Barrett
item.description: To combat fake solar eclipse glasses, the American Paper Optics team created the Core Four elements of eclipse glasses to look out for to ensure your safety during the solar event.

media:content.media:text: Students smile as they watch the eclipse with their glasses on.
media:content.media:description: Students watch the solar eclipse emerge from behind clouds in Chicago in 2017.

media:content.media:text: A combination of people and machines make eclipse glasses at American Paper Optics' manufacturing facility.
media:content.media:description: A combination of people and machines make eclipse glasses at American Paper Optics' manufacturing facility.

media:content.media:text: Seventeen pairs of glasses are printed on each large sheet of double laminated paperboard, before being fed into a machine in stacks, where a massive hole punch knocks out the center eye holes.
media:content.media:description: Seventeen pairs of glasses are printed on each large sheet of double laminated paperboard, before being fed into a machine in stacks, where a massive hole punch knocks out the center eye holes.

media:content.media:text: The many different brand versions of American Paper Optics glasses made in preparation for the upcoming eclipse are on display.
media:content.media:description: The many different brand versions of American Paper Optics glasses made in preparation for the upcoming eclipse are on display.

item.title: Biden and Xi Jinping discuss Russia-Ukraine war, Taiwan, election security and counternarcotics
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Bacallao and Summer Concepcion and Dawn Liu and Tara Prindiville and Emily Hung
item.description: Biden held a call with Chinese President Xi Jinping to address China’s trade with Russia amid the war in Ukraine, cyberattacks and election interference, and counternarcotics efforts, a senior administration official said.

media:content.media:text: Xi Jinping and Joe Biden at the G20 Summit in Bali
media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping and Joe Biden at the G20 Summit in Bali, on Nov. 14, 2022.

item.title: Tornado threats, heavy rain and snow expected as dangerous spring storms threaten millions
item.dc:creator: Minyvonne Burke and Kathryn Prociv and Steve Strouss
item.description: Millions of people are under weather alerts as a dangerous storm system moves through parts of the Ohio Valley region and the Northeast, bringing heavy rain, threats of isolated tornadoes and snow.

media:content.media:text: Heavy rain causes flooding near the area of North High St. in Columbus, Ohio, on April 2, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Heavy rain causes flooding near the area of North High St. in Columbus, Ohio, on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:description: Watch live coverage as White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre holds a press briefing.

item.title: Florida man sentenced to 14 months in prison for threatening to kill Supreme Court justice
item.dc:creator: Antonio Planas and Polly DeFrank
item.description: A Florida man was sentenced to 14 months in prison for threatening to kill a Supreme Court justice last year, federal prosecutors said Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: The Supreme Court in Washington.
media:content.media:description: The Supreme Court in Washington.

item.title: Biden calls chef José Andrés after Israeli strike kills World Central Kitchen aid workers
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Shabad and Yuliya Talmazan and Kelly O'Donnell and Ghael Fobes
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden has called world-renowned chef José Andrés "to express that he's heartbroken" after an Israeli airstrike killed seven aid workers in Gaza from the chef's World Central Kitchen organization.

media:content.media:text: Chef Jose Andres in Spain on Oct. 10, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Chef Jose Andres in Spain on Oct. 10, 2023.

item.title: Video shows dramatic rescue of hiker clinging to side of California cliff as ocean rises below
item.dc:creator: Noah Osborne
item.description: The dramatic helicopter rescue of a man who clung to a Northern California cliffside after falling off a trail in the Golden Gate National Recreation Area was caught on video released by the Sonoma County Sheriff’s Office.

media:content.media:text: California Officials rescue hiker who hung from cliff.
media:content.media:description: California Officials rescue hiker who hung from cliff.

item.title: Miranda Lambert, Billie Eilish, Nicki Minaj sign letter to AI developers to honor artists' rights
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: More than 200 artists signed an open letter calling on artificial intelligence tech companies to stop using AI “to infringe upon and devalue the rights of human artists."

media:content.media:text: Image: Finneas, left, and Billie Eilish perform "What Was I Made For?
media:content.media:description: Finneas, left, and Billie Eilish perform "What Was I Made For?" from "Barbie" during the Oscars on March 10, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles.

item.title: Biden to hold downsized Ramadan events after Muslim leaders decline invitations
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba
item.description: President Joe Biden plans to hold a quiet, dramatically downsized iftar gathering Tuesday night after invitations were declined by several Muslim American community leaders, according to two sources familiar with the planning.

item.title: After big loss against Iowa, LSU's Angel Reese says she's been getting death threats for a year
item.dc:creator: Curtis Bunn
item.description: Angel Reese, the LSU basketball star who led her team to the NCAA women’s national championship a year ago, told reporters that she's been getting death threats for a year.

media:content.media:text: Angel Reese
media:content.media:description: Angel Reese on Monday in Albany, N.Y.

item.title: Jay Leno's wife 'sometimes does not know her husband' after dementia diagnosis, court docs say
item.dc:creator: Diana Dasrath and Mirna Alsharif
item.description: Jay Leno's wife, Mavis Leno, suffers from advanced dementia and "sometimes does not know her husband, Jay, nor her date of birth," a lawyer said in approving Leno's conservatorship petition.

media:content.media:text: Jay Leno with his wife Mavis Leno arrive at an event in West Hollywood in 2017.
media:content.media:description: Jay Leno with his wife Mavis Leno in West Hollywood, Calif., in 2017.

item.title: Elon Musk's X appoints new safety chiefs as it seeks to rebuild ads business
item.dc:creator: David Ingram
item.description: Elon Musk’s X said Tuesday it was appointing two new employees to oversee safety on the platform.

media:content.media:text: Image: The "X" sign atop the company headquarters
media:content.media:description: The "X" sign atop the headquarters for the company, formerly known as Twitter, in San Francisco on July 28, 2023.

item.title: Wisconsin governor vetoes transgender high school athletics ban
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers has vetoed a bill that would have banned high school transgender athletes from competing on teams that align with their gender identity.

media:content.media:text: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers.
media:content.media:description: Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers in Madison, Wisc., on March 21, 2019.
